description: This research seminar explores the way in which human rights have been used to address egregious violations committed by state agents in various Latin American countries. Case studies and thematic human rights responses will be analyzed. Additionally, the operation of the Inter-American human rights protection system will be examined in cases of state repression. A substantial part of the course centers on the ongoing struggle against impunity of perpetrators of gross violations in Latin American countries. Outstanding questions include: How has the human rights regime been used in Latin America to frame claims against state repression? Has the regional human rights protection system been effective in addressing situations of gross violations? Have human rights-related criminal prosecutions been successful in the region? What are the current challenges in confronting state abuse and impunity of perpetrators in Latin America? Course reading draws on relevant literature in political science and law, including textbooks, academic articles, legal decisions, and international treaties and other legal instruments. Complementarily, films (fiction and documentary) will be used to offer a human dimension of the problems being analyzed.
